titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Marilyn Horne Foundation Records, 1991-2011 CTC.2010.01
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by William Daw.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2018-06-06T13:02-0400

did.abstract: The Marilyn Horne Foundation was formed in 1993 to promote the art of the vocal recital. Renowned mezzo soprano opera star Marilyn Horne wanted to support young recitalists and give them the opportunity to hone their craft. The records include financial information, artist information, board of trustee files, marketing materials, video and audio recordings, photographs, and posters.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Gift of the Marilyn Horne Foundation in 2010.

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: The University of Pittsburgh holds the property rights to the material in this collection, but the copyright may still be held by the original creator/author. Researchers are therefore advised to follow the regulations set forth in the U.S. Copyright Code when publishing, quoting, or reproducing material from this collection without the consent of the creator/author or that go beyond what is allowed by fair use.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This collection details the entire history of the Marilyn Horne Foundation and its efforts to promote young classical singers and the art of the vocal recital. The materials are arranged into four series: Office Files, Programs and Events, Photographs, and Audio/Visual Recordings. Included in the collection is information on the artists that performed for and were sponsored by the foundation; files on the development, marketing, and finances of the foundation; board of trustees meeting minutes; and a large amount of materials on the Foundation's education program in New York City and also its national residency program. The Foundation's two main productions, The Song Continues annual concert and the On Wings of Song recital program, are both covered in great detail.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was processed by Aleksandra Pomiecko, Margaret Huang, and William Daw in 2011-2013.

bioghist.head: History
bioghist.p: The Marilyn Horne Foundation (MHF) was formed in 1993 to promote the art of the vocal recital. Marilyn Horne is widely recognized as one of the greatest opera performers in history. Ms. Horne started her foundation because she grew worried that the tradition of the song recital was disappearing. The eminent opera star wanted to support young recitalists and give them the opportunity to refine their craft. She acknowledged that there still seemed to be eager audiences for song recitals in cities like New York, but at the time, Ms. Horne noted that institutions and organizations around the country that used to present song recital series regularly started dropping out of the business.

The Marilyn Horne Foundation was one of the most influential and esteemed national nonprofits devoted exclusively to song and to gifted young vocal recitalists. The Foundation was officially launched on January 16, 1994, with a gala concert at Carnegie Hall celebrating Ms. Horne's 60th birthday. The mission statement of the Foundation was "to encourage, support and preserve the art of the vocal recital through the presentation of recitals and related educational activities in communities across the United States."

The Marilyn Horne Foundation achieved this mission through the presentation of recitals, residencies, concerts, radio broadcasts, educational outreach and song commissions. In addition to performances at Carnegie Hall and the Julliard School of Music, the Foundation performed hundreds of recitals at schools, colleges, and universities across the country. The Foundation sponsored “The Song Continues,” which was a weeklong festival of master classes and recitals culminating with an annual concert.

The Foundation selected a number of aspiring young singers to send on the road for four-day residencies in partnership with community-based concert presenters, music festivals or colleges. The singers offered recitals and visited local schools. The first two singers sponsored by the Foundation were soprano Bridgett Hooks and tenor Olafur Bjarnason. There was also a competition, held in July for students enrolled at the Music Academy for the West in Santa Barbara, California, where Marilyn Horne served as a voice program director from 1977. Two winners (a singer and pianist) were presented each season at the “Wings of Song” recital in New York.

The Foundation also supported the “On Wings of Song” program which started in 1995 as a vocal recital series and later included radio broadcasts on WQXR. Marilyn Horne and WQXR’s Elliot Forrest co-hosted an hour that consisted of part concert, part master-class, and part reminiscence. The concerts were recorded live at Christ & Stephen’s Church in New York City. The program was eventually folded into “The Song Continues” series.

Over the course of the fifteen year plus history of the Foundation, over 100 artists were sponsored. In July 2010, the Foundation closed and the programs of the Marilyn Horne Foundation were incorporated into the Weill Music Institute at Carnegie Hall with Marilyn Horne serving as the Artistic Advisor. Both The Song Continues, the annual festival, and the On Wings of Song vocal recital series live on to introduce and support emerging young vocalists.

arrangement.p: The records of the Marilyn Horne Foundation are organized into five series:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains the office files of the Marilyn Horne Foundation. It is divided into eight subseries containing materials on the artists who performed for the foundation, Board of Trustees meetings, development files, budget and financial materials, general office files, marketing files, and finally there are two subseries on the numerous residency programs that the foundation sponsored nationally and in the New York City area. Some of these subseries are broken down into smaller sections.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Artists subseries is divided into two sections: Pianists and Vocal Artists. Each contains folders for individual performers that were contracted for performance by the Marilyn Horne Foundation and includes contracts, programs, photographs, newspaper clippings, and correspondence. The folders are arranged alphabetically by the artist's last name.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains the files that pertain to the Marilyn Horne Foundation's Board of Trustees. The subseries is split into two sections containing general files about the Board and its' members and the meeting minutes of the Board throughout its' existence. The Board of Trustee files are filed in alphabetical order by folder title and the meeting minutes are filed in chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Development subseries includes materials on the various organizations that granted and donated funds to the Marilyn Horne Foundation. Two of the major contributing groups were the National Endowment for the Arts and the New York State Council on the Arts. Included are correspondence, grant applications, reports, and other materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Marketing subseries contains a variety of materials that were used to promote the Foundation and its efforts including informational pamphlets, materials mailed to members, newspaper clippings, etc. The files are arranged in alphabetical order. Two items worth noting are a complete run of the Foundation's Sing On! newsletter and files detailing the planning and production of an educational video showing an introduction to classical song for a young audience.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Marilyn Horne Foundation sponsored residencies for artists all over the country. Young artists were featured in an educational program, which was followed by a recital for pre-college students. This subseries is arranged alphabetically by name. There are also files for each school or festival which contain correspondence with the venues, contracts, marketing information, programs, budgets, etc. The students and teachers were sometimes surveyed after their performances; these surveys are filed at the end of each school's residency folder.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Marilyn Horne Foundation participated in several New York City area educational programs. The Foundation partnered with several New York City schools and the Education Through Music program, whose aim was to promote the integration of music into the curriculum of disadvantaged schools. This subseries is arranged alphabetically by folder title. There are files for each school that contain the surveys that were conducted after the performance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains materials on the programs and events of the Marilyn Horne Foundation. It is divided into four subseries: Benefits and Other Events; the Music Academy of the West; On Wings of Song recital series; and the Song Continues Annual Event.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains planning materials on several benefits and fund raising events that were held by the Marilyn Horne Foundation. Materials include correspondence, financial papers, invitations, programs, and other materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Music Academy of the West is an institution which, like the Marilyn Horne Foundation, is committed to the development of the next generation of classical musicians. Marilyn Horne, who studied under Lotte Lehmann at the Academy as a teenager, accepted the position of Voice Program Director in 1997 and consequently the two groups have been in close collaboration ever since. This subseries contains materials for each of the Music Academy of the West's Summer Festivals between 1997 and 2009. Each year's folders contain correspondence, financial papers, reviews, advertising, programs, and other materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: On Wings of Song is the Marilyn Horne Foundation's monthly vocal recital program which features young artists. Many of these recitals were later broadcast on New York City's WQXR radio station. For several years the performances were also brodcast of the Chicago station WFMT. This subseries is arranged chronologically. Within each year, there are files on the artists for that season, programs, marketing information, commissions, and other materials.

did.unittitle: On Wings of Song radio syndication,
On Wings of Song radio syndication,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Song Continues... Festival is the Marilyn Horne Foundation's annual festival that focuses on the art song. The annual festival included the gala concert, several masterclass by world-renown singers, vocal seminars, and other duo recitals by the Foundation's roster of artists. This subseries is arranged chronologically and includes files on all of the events of that festival for each given year including correspondence with the venues, marketing information, budgets, etc.

The Benefits and the National Residency program photos are arranged alphabettically while the other two subseries are arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: There were over 200 audio recordings that were included with the Marilyn Horne Foundation's records. These recordings were never made commercially available. Most of these recordings are on CDs, but a small amount are on audio cassettes. There are also nearly 150 video recordings on DVD, VHS, Mini DV, and Beta SP.

These recordings are divided into three subseries. Each subseries is arranged in chronological order. Each performance contains a note with venue and artist information, the format of the recording, and the length.

did.unittitle: National Residency Program and other recordings,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains recordings of recitals presented by the Horne Foundation's national residency program. Also included in this subseries are a small collection of videos that were sent out to schools and performing arts groups that were prospects to participate in the program. These recordings are arranged in chronological order. Each performance contains a note with venue and artist information, the format of the recording, and the length.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Song Continues... Festival is the Marilyn Horne Foundation's annual festival that focuses on the art song. The annual festival included the gala concert, several masterclass by world-renown singers, vocal seminars, and other duo recitals by the Foundation's roster of artists. These recordings are arranged in chronological order. Each performance contains a note with venue and artist information, the format of the recording, and the length.

scopecontent.p: Song Continues annual recital: 15th Anniversary Concert and Marilyn’s ‘Diamond’ Birthday at the Isaac Stern Auditorium at Carnegie Hall, NYC.
Presented by the Marilyn Horne Foundation and the Weill Music Institute at Carnegie Hall.

Meredit Arwady, contralto; William Bolcom, piano; Nicole Cabell, soprano; David Daniels, countertenor; Joyce Didonato, mezzo soprano; Susan Graham, mezzo soprano; Thomas Hampson, baritone; Dmitri Hvorostovsky, baritone; Warren Jones, piano; Martin Katz, piano; Isabel Leonard, mezzo soprano; Lester Lynch, baritone; Carrie-Ann Matheson, piano; Karita Mattila, soprano; James Morris, bass baritone; Thomas Quasthoff, bass baritone; Bruce Sledge, tenor; Dolora Zajick, mezzo soprano; Brian Zeger, piano; Hosted by Frederica von Stade and Samuel Ramey.

Also are included are a series of birthday tributes from Marilyn Horne's friends and family; including Florence Henderson, Jim Nabors, Carol Burnett, Barbara Cook, Joan Sutherland, and Lotfi Mansouri.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains posters advertising the Horne Foundation's On Wings of Song and Song Continues programs along with posters relating to their national residency program recitals. The posters are arranged in alphabetical order by the location of the residency or the name of the show. Please note that some of the Song Continues posters in this series are oversized and are located at the Archives Service Center.
